member.name: F:Rebex.Security.Cryptography.CryptMD5Digest._digestChallenge
member.summary:
Description of digest algorithm:
digest-challenge = 1#( realm | nonce | qop-options | stale | maxbuf | charset algorithm | cipher-opts | auth-param ) realm = "realm" "=" " realm-value " realm-value = qdstr-val nonce = "nonce" "=" "nonce-value " nonce-value = qdstr-val qop-options = "qop" "=" " qop-list " qop-list = 1#qop-value qop-value = "auth" | "auth-int" | "auth-conf" | token stale = "stale" "=" "true" maxbuf = "maxbuf" "=" maxbuf-value maxbuf-value = 1*DIGIT charset = "charset" "=" "utf-8" algorithm = "algorithm" "=" "md5-sess" cipher-opts = "cipher" "=" "1#cipher-value" cipher-value = "3des" | "des" | "rc4-40" | "rc4" | "rc4-56" | token auth-param = token "=" ( token | quoted-string )

member.name: M:Rebex.Net.Imap.CheckForUpdates(System.Int32)
member.summary: Processes server notifications for the specified amount of time.
member.param: Duration of the idle interval, in miliseconds.
member.returns: True if any new notifications were received.

remarks.p: Notifications are generated when a new message arrives, when a message is deleted, when message flags change, etc. (see for a list of supported notifications).

These notifications can occur during a call to any method and are reported using the event. The method is useful when you need to check for any possible changes (reported using notifications) and do not wish to call any other method. Typically, a client application will call periodically while idle.
To receive the notifications itself, use the event.
This method represents IMAP NOOP or IDLE commands. IDLE is used whenever the server supports this command - see property. For duration values less than 10, NOOP is always used.

member.name: M:Rebex.Net.Imap.SendCommand(System.String,System.Object[])
member.summary: Executes a command on the IMAP server.
member.param: Command (eg. "CAPABILITY").
List of parameters. Allowed types are and a byte array.
member.returns: Unique ID of the message, or null (Nothing in Visual Basic) if the server does not support this feature.

remarks.p:
The specified string parameters are send as is. It is caller's responsibility to properly format the parameters.
The specified byte array parameters are send as literals - binary blocks of data.
To use this method properly, some understanding of the IMAP protocol is strongly recommended.
A call to SendCommand Must be followed by a call to ReadResponse method.
Use ReadResponse and SendCommand to implement various custom commands.
After a successful call to SendCommand, the object will be in Reading state.
The object must be Ready state when calling this method.

member.name: M:Rebex.Net.Imap.ReadResponse
member.summary: Returns the response of the IMAP server to the command.
member.returns: Response of the IMAP server.

remarks.p: Must be preceeded by a call to SendCommand method. (Or, more exactly, the must be Reading.
Use ReadResponse and SendCommand to implement various custom commands.
After a successful call to ReadResponse, the object will be in Reading state.

member.name: M:Rebex.Net.Imap.BeginCheckForUpdates(System.AsyncCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Begins asynchronous CheckForUpdates operation. Processes server notifications.
member.returns: An that references the asynchronous operation.

remarks.p: Notifications are generated when a new message arrives, when a message is deleted, when message flags change, etc. (see for a list of supported notifications).

These notifications can occur during a call to any method and are reported using the event. The method is useful when you need to check for any possible changes (reported using notifications) and do not wish to call any other method. Typically, a client application will call periodically while idle.
To receive the notifications itself, use the event.
This method represents IMAP NOOP command.

member.param: An optional asynchronous callback to be called when the operation is complete.
A user-provided object that identifies this particular asynchronous operation.

member.returns: An that references the asynchronous operation.

remarks.p: Notifications are generated when a new message arrives, when a message is deleted, when message flags change, etc. (see for a list of supported notifications).

These notifications can occur during a call to any method and are reported using the event. The method is useful when you need to check for any possible changes (reported using notifications) and do not wish to call any other method. Typically, a client application will call periodically while idle.
To receive the notifications itself, use the event.
This method represents IMAP NOOP or IDLE commands. IDLE is used whenever the server supports this command - see property.

member.param: An optional asynchronous callback to be called when the operation is complete.
A user-provided object that identifies this particular asynchronous operation.

member.name: M:Rebex.Net.Imap.BeginStoreRawMessage(System.String,System.IO.Stream,Rebex.Net.ImapMessageFlags,Rebex.Mime.Headers.MailDateTime,System.AsyncCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Begins asynchronous StoreRawMessage operation. Uploads the contents of the stream to the specified folder and sets its flags and date.
member.param: Folder that will receive the message.
The input stream.
Message flags.
IMAP message date/time
member.returns: Unique ID of the message, or null (Nothing in Visual Basic) if the server does not support this feature.

remarks.p: Caution: Unlike the StoreMessage methods, StoreRawMessage does not parse the message to validate its structure and retrieve its date/time. User must ensure the stream supplied to this method represents a valid MIME format message.

The stream must contain data in MIME format, other formats are not supported. MIME files often have the '.eml' extension and are produced by Outlook Express. In contrast, Outlook produces '.msg' files that are not MIME files and therefore cannot be uploaded using this method.
This method represents IMAP APPEND command.
Unique ID of the message will be returned if the server supports the .UniqueIdPlus extension and it is enabled. See and .

member.param: An optional asynchronous callback to be called when the operation is complete.
A user-provided object that identifies this particular asynchronous operation.
member.returns: An that references the asynchronous operation.

member.name: M:Rebex.Net.Imap.BeginSendCommand(System.String,System.Object[],System.AsyncCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Begins asynchronous SendCommand operation. Executes a command on the IMAP server.
member.param: Command (eg. "CAPABILITY").
List of parameters. Allowed types are and a byte array.

remarks.p:
The specified string parameters are send as is. It is caller's responsibility to properly format the parameters.
The specified byte array parameters are send as literals - binary blocks of data.
To use this method properly, some understanding of the IMAP protocol is strongly recommended.
A call to SendCommand Must be followed by a call to ReadResponse method.
Use ReadResponse and SendCommand to implement various custom commands.
After a successful call to SendCommand, the object will be in Reading state.
The object must be Ready state when calling this method.

member.param: An optional asynchronous callback to be called when the operation is complete.
A user-provided object that identifies this particular asynchronous operation.
member.returns: An that references the asynchronous operation.

member.summary: Ends a pending asynchronous SendCommand operation.

member.name: P:Rebex.Net.Imap.Timeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the length of time before the operation times out (specify -1 or 0 to indicate that the request does not time out).
member.value: The length of time, in milliseconds, until the operation times out, or the value -1 or 0 to indicate that the request does not time out. Default is 60000 (60 seconds).

remarks.p: The internal timeout counter is reset every time data is sent or received from to server.
The property affects both synchronous and asynchronous methods.

member.value: The length of time, in milliseconds, until the abort operation times out. Default is 3000, which seems to be a reasonable value.
